General symptoms of a stroke include sudden onset of: numbness, weakness, or paralysis of the face, arm, or leg, typically on one side of the body; trouble seeing in one or both eyes, such as dimness, blurring, double vision, or loss of vision; confusion, trouble understanding; slurred or garbled speech; trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination; or severe headache.Certain diseases or conditions increase your risk of stroke such as high blood pressure,  diabetes;  Having diabetes doubles your risk of stroke because of the circulation problems associated with the disease; high cholesterol; coronary artery disease, which can lead to heart attack and stroke.Certain behaviors can increase your risk of stroke. These include: smoking, physical inactivity; overweight; heavy use of alcohol,  and illegal drug use. You can read more about this through this link: http://www.webmd.com/stroke/guide/stroke-overview-factsTake care and keep us posted.

question: I am trying to quit smoking and just have to say no to the habit.  what kind of scares me is when I take a deep drag off a cigarette I get double vision of distant objects.  I am wondering if that is a sign of a stroke coming since I assume that the double vision is caused by the constricting of a blood vessel somewhere which cuts off the oxygen.  But thats just my theory.  I am going to have a physical soon and talk to the doctor about that.  Anyone have any ideas on this symptom?
title: can smoking cigs cause a stroke?
